subject: Law
title: Genocide and the Duty to Prevent
description: A quick, practical guide to Genocide and the Duty to Prevent.

hook.text: Rwanda, 1994. 800,000 people killed in 100 days. The world watched. The Genocide Convention demanded action.

buildup.text: The 1948 Genocide Convention defines genocide and obligates states to prevent and punish it.

discovery.text: Genocide means acts committed to destroy, in whole or in part, a national, ethnic, racial, or religious group.

twist.text: The duty to prevent existsâ€”but enforcement failed in Rwanda, Srebrenica, and Darfur. The law existed; the will didn't.

climax.text: The ICJ ruled in 2007 that Serbia violated its duty to prevent genocide at Srebrenicaâ€”a landmark decision.

punchline.text: The law says 'never again.' History keeps testing that promise.

quiz.question: What does the Genocide Convention obligate states to do?
options: Only punish genocide after it occurs
